entry.title: Mejorando tu Comprensión del Libro de Inventarios y Balances de Perú: Nueva Documentación
entry.content:
Soy Maitê, desarrolladora de asistencia al usuario en SAP Globalization, y trabajo en el área financiera. Como parte de mi rol, me complace compartir las últimas actualizaciones en la documentación del reporte Libro de Inventarios y Balances de Perú en SAP Document and Reporting Compliance. Explora los aspectos destacados a continuación para descubrir cómo estas mejoras pueden ayudarte con el reporte!

El reporte

El Libro de Inventarios y Balances de Perú está actualmente disponible en SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition y SAP S/4HANA. El reporte organiza los saldos de las cuentas de mayor en catorce libros, siguiendo los requerimientos del PCGE (Plan Contable General Empresarial) y de la SUNAT (Superintendencia Nacional de Aduanas y de Administración Tributaria).

Mejoras recientes en la documentación

Para ayudarte a comprender mejor el reporte, hemos añadido una página nueva a la documentación. Esta nueva página proporciona detalles sobre campos específicos, agrupados según configuraciones y características. Nuestro objetivo es aclarar las relaciones entre ciertos campos del reporte y las configuraciones necesarias antes de ejecutarlo.
Nueva página agregada en SAP Help Portal

 

Tablas estructuradas para mayor claridad

Hemos organizado la documentación en cinco tablas:

  • Tabla 1: Campos relacionados con las jerarquías FSV y G/L Account

Esta tabla destaca los campos asociados con la configuración de jerarquías de la aplicación Manage Global Hierarchies y se enfoca en dos tipos de jerarquía: Financial Statement Versions (FSV) y G/L Account.

  • Tabla 2: Campos relacionados con el plan de cuentas alternativo

Detalla los campos relacionados con la configuración del plan de cuentas alternativo usado para requerimientos legales específicos en Perú.

  • Tabla 3: Campos Tax Number Type y Tax Number relacionados con el plan de cuentas alternativo

Ofrece detalles sobre campos relacionados con impuestos asociados a la configuración del plan de cuentas alternativo.

  • Tabla 4: Otros campos en el reporte

Proporciona información sobre otros campos, explicando sus fuentes de datos y cómo los completa el sistema.

  • Tabla 5: Campos opcionales en el reporte

Por último, esta tabla presenta los campos opcionales incluidos en nuestra solución y explica cómo los completa el sistema, aunque no son requeridos por la SUNAT.

Conclusión

Esperamos que estas actualizaciones en la documentación faciliten tu trabajo con el reporte Libro de Inventarios y Balances. Puedes encontrarlas en la documentación del reporte enlazada abajo:

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: Inventory and Balance Ledger
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition y SAP S/4HANA: Inventory and Balance Ledger

Te invitamos a explorar estas tablas en el SAP Help Portal y a compartir cualquier pregunta o comentarios que tengas. ¡Serán bienvenidos!

Por último, pero no menos importante, sigue SAP Document and Reporting Compliance en la comunidad para recibir actualizaciones.

Gracias y hasta la próxima,

Maitê Bohn

entry.title: My Expert Playlist - SAP TechEd 2025
entry.content:
Hello, dear influencers, experts, and friends from the SAP Community!

It’s finally that time of the year again: SAP TechEd Season!
This year feels extra special to me—it’s the first SAP TechEd happening in Germany since I moved here, and I couldn’t be more excited.

When it comes to building my personal TechEd agenda, it has never been both so easy and so difficult at the same time.

Why difficult?
Because my curiosity is endless. Over my (long) SAP career, I’ve worked across many areas: from writing ABAP code to designing modern user interfaces, from integration to solution and enterprise architecture—where technology truly meets business. I love exploring how technology and business merge, so naturally, I’d like to attend almost every session across the board.

Why easy?
Because priorities are clear this year: AI.
My laser focus will be on everything around custom AI scenarios—how we as engineers can build AI extensions, create and extend Joule AI agents, and leverage the SAP AI Foundation. I believe many of the new challenges (and opportunities!) will emerge here, and I can’t wait to discover how SAP’s newest innovations will empower us.

That said, I’ve shortlisted around 30 sessions I’d love to attend. Realistically, some I’ll have to catch later via SAP TechEd Virtual—but here are my Top 3 “must-watch” sessions:

 

My Top 3 SAP TechEd 2025 Sessions

  • CT1245 | Hugging Face Transformers in AI Foundation
    I’m learning to use Hugging Face models, so I’m curious to see how they work within the SAP AI Foundation. This feels like a new superpower for building advanced AI scenarios.

  • AI160 | Build your own AI agent–based solution with the generative AI hub
    Agents are another game-changing technology. Spending two hours diving deep into building custom AI agents to extend SAP products sounds like time very well invested.

  • PAR102 | From MCP to Joule: Unlocking SAP data and AI innovation with Microsoft
    I’ve been exploring how SAP AI Foundation can be integrated with cloud providers beyond the Generative AI Hub. This session will be a great opportunity to hear directly from Microsoft experts on their approach.

  • Bonus: AI101 | Optimize prompts and explore models with the generative AI hub
    Prompt engineering is one of the core skills for creating effective custom AI solutions. This session promises plenty of practical insights to sharpen that skill.

Of course, I wish I could attend everything—but thankfully, many sessions will be available later via SAP TechEd Virtual.

In addition to the AI-focused ones, I’ll also keep a close eye on all sessions related to Joule in the context of ABAP and CAP development—because at the end of the day, AI custom scenarios often start right there (with a little help from Python).

Final Thoughts

To all my fellow SAP Community colleagues:
I wish you an inspiring and knowledge-packed SAP TechEd season. May your curiosity be fueled and your learning appetite at least partly satisfied.

Let’s keep in touch and exchange our learnings in the weeks to come.

All the best,
Douglas

entry.title: New Clean Core Extensibility KPIs arrive on the RISE with SAP Dashboard
entry.content:
Clean Core Extensibility Model goes RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard

We are thrilled to introduce another significant update to the RISE with SAP Methodology dashboard, delivering more transparent and structured insights into the clean core status of your custom extensions.

The latest release of the RISE with SAP Methodology dashboard in SAP Cloud ALM integrates SAP's new Clean Core Level Concept, an enhanced maturity model that categorizes extensions into four levels (A, B, C, and D) based on their architectural integrity and upgrade safety.

Updated Clean Core Extensibility Model

 

To power these new insights, the dashboard now supports the manual import of check results from the ABAP Test Cockpit (ATC).

Note:

As a prerequisite, you need to add the required ATC checks for clean core to your existing global standard ATC check variant. Relevant ATC checks for clean core are:

  • Allowed SAP enhancement technologies
  • Usage of APIs
  • Critical Statements

Your ATC variant can also include additional ATC checks. However, please be aware that these are not taken into account for the display in the RISE with SAP Methodology dashboard but will result in a larger ATC Check export file which again may cause the file import to fail (maximum file size is restricted to 100 MB).

 

Highlights of this Release

** Technical Debt Score **

This new KPI provides an aggregated score representing the technical debt of all custom objects in your system. It is weighted based on the severity of references to SAP objects, with a higher score indicating greater technical debt. A three-month trend indicates an increase or decrease in the score and thus helps you monitor whether your system's maintainability is improving or not.

Technical Debt Score KPI in System View of RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard

 

** Clean Core Share **

The Clean Core Share offers a comprehensive overview of how your system’s custom objects are distributed across the A-D clean core levels. This visualization helps you:

  • visualize your system’s custom code distribution
  • quickly identify areas needing immediate attention and improvement (e.g. decreasing the share of Level D Objects)
  • track improvement over time
  • make strategic decisions to achieve a clean core

Distribution of customer objects across clean core levels

 

These enhancements underscore our commitment to providing an actionable and comprehensive dashboard.
We encourage you to leverage these new features to guide your strategic decisions and ensure a successful clean core journey.

For more information about extensibility-related KPIs in RISE with SAP Methodology dashboard, see https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-alm/applicationhelp/extensibility?locale=en-US on SAP Help Portal.

 Stay tuned for more…

entry.title: Re: CDS view I_EQUIPMENTDATA for BW extraction: Why shoul...
entry.content:
Hi Yvonne,

"... do not enhance e.g. cds view i_equipmentdata directly, it will work but this will cause trouble during the next update. "

------------------------

There's code correction note for this standard CDS, like: 3193300 - I_EquipmentData - numeric overflow dump So if custom coding is implemented in this CDS, the next update (with note implementation or system upgrade ) may impact the customization. 

However if you use 'extend view I_EquipmentData with Z_E_I_EQUIPMENTDATA' without changing the I_EquipmentData itself, it'll be OK.

Regards,

entry.title: What's new: SAP Best Practices for SAP Integrated Business Planning – 2511
entry.content:
In this blog, we will explore the latest updates to SAP Best Practices for SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP). I will focus on the key highlights and new features introduced with release 2511. 

Enhancements in the SAPIBP1 Sample Planning Area:

In the latest updates to the SAPIBP1 sample planning area, the following main enhancements have been introduced.

  • Supply lead time calculations in inventory optimization algorithms previously used equal statistical weight of historical data from all past periods. With the introduction of the two new key figures for production and transportation lead time for historical recency factor, you can now apply a factor, giving more weight to recent periods while reducing the influence of older ones.
  • To improve data clarity and the usability of the planning area, we have simplified the calculation and decimal settings of several key figures.

 New Content for Sample Planning Area I_SAPIBP2:

We are now offering 17 new solution processes for the new planning area, Integrated Business Planning (I_SAPIBP2). In general, we have migrated and improved the existing solution processes, which were based on the Unified Planning Area (SAPIBP1) and Order-Based Planning using Flexible Master Data (SAP7F). As a guiding principle, we are delivering the most important solution processes with release 2511 and plan to deliver the remaining solution processes in subsequent releases.

The following figure provides an overview of the solution processes included in the 2511 delivery. As shown, solution processes are available for all IBP applications. Additionally, we have renamed the Sales & Operations Planning (S&OP) process to Sales, Inventory, and Operations Planning (SIOP), as an inventory review step has now been included in this process.

Overview solution processes based on planning area I_SAPIBP2

Content-wise, this package includes Excel planning views, planner workspaces, analytic stories, and sample data, all adapted and ready to be used for the I_SAPIBP2 planning area. Of course, you will also find a detailed configuration guide describing the setup activities required to deploy SAP Best Practices for SAP Integrated Business Planning, as well as detailed test scripts outlining the step-by-step execution of the solution processes in the system. All information about the new solution processes is available on the SAP Signavio Process Navigator.

Here are two examples of an analytic story and a planner workspace based on the planning area I_SAPIBP2.

Planner Workspace based on planning area I_SAPIBP2

Analytic story based on planning area I_SAPIBP2

Adding Joule and generative AI capabilities

In several solution processes, we have added the use of Joule and generative AI features. For example, we describe how you can utilize Joule capabilities for job scheduling in the solution process IBP Advanced Demand – Segmentation (7LB). Another example is the use of the Master Data Health Check job with Joule, which provides functionalities for ensuring master data consistency. This usage is described in solution processes for inbound integration, such as IBP Foundation – Inbound Real-Time Integration with SAP S/4HANA (7LN), or IBP – Time-Series-Based Inbound Integration with SAP S/4HANA (3OF).

We have also added additional steps to show how generative AI can assist you in your day-to-day work. In our content, we now describe how you can use generative AI to analyze forecast results in the solution processes IBP for Demand – Demand Planning (11V) and IBP Advanced Demand – Demand Planning (7L6). In addition, the AI-Assisted Inventory Analysis is now available in the solution processes IBP for Inventory (11Z) and IBP Advanced Inventory Optimization – Inventory Planning (7LC).

The screenshot shows an example of how generative AI can be used to analyze forecast results.

Generative AI analyzing forecast results.

IBP for maintenance, repair, and operations (MRO)

The solution process for IBP for maintenance, repair, and operations (MRO) (75C) has been enhanced to support inventory balancing and the inventory review process. Inventory balancing is used to distribute spare parts among different locations to avoid excess inventory at one site while shortages occur at another. In the inventory review process, the system recommends reorder points and safety stocks to improve the planning process, and it compares the current inventory parameters in the ERP system with those recommended in IBP.

Planner Workspace MRO

Sample Excel Planning Views

Another enhancement is a change in the handling of ActiveX controls in the SAP IBP add-in for Microsoft Excel. Until now, ActiveX controls were used in our Excel templates, for example, to store information about the planning view or for the chart section. With this release, all sample Excel planning views are based on the new sample VBA template, which uses Form controls instead of ActiveX controls (see SAP Note 1790530). For further information about ActiveX controls and the SAP IBP add-in for Microsoft Excel, see What's New in SAP IBP 2511: Changed Handling of ActiveX Controls.

Here some more useful links:

  • Highlight video of the new solution processes for Planning Area I_SAPIBP2
  • SAP Signavio Process Navigator to download all assets of SAP Best Practices for SAP Integrated Business Planning
  • Never heard about SAP Best Practices for SAP Integrated Business Planning – check out this short video for more information
  • In case you want to learn more about SAP Best Practices for SAP Integrated Business Planning for Supply Chain I recommend our blog series. The first blog is available here.
  • What's New blog about SAP Integrated Business Planning 2511 is available here

Thank you for reading our release highlights blog. Stay tuned for more updates and enhancements in future releases.

entry.title: Explore the potential of SAP Fiori development portal using complex building blocks (3 of 6)
entry.content:
In our previous posts, we introduced the SAP Fiori development portal and explored its structure. Now it's time to see the real power in action. Complex building blocks like the table don't just display data - they bring intelligent behavior, enterprise-grade features, and multiple visualization options that adapt to your business needs. Let's dive into how the portal helps you explore and understand these sophisticated capabilities.

Beyond Visual Display: Intelligent Behavior

The table building block exemplifies how SAP Fiori elements transforms simple annotations into comprehensive business functionality. When you annotate your UI.LineItems, you're not just defining columns - you're enabling a complete data management experience.

The table automatically adapts its behavior based on your entity's capabilities which are defined in the service metadata and annotations, for example:

  • Insertable entities enable users to create new records directly in the table
  • Deletable entities provide deletion capabilities with proper confirmation dialogs
  • Updatable entities allow inline editing, with optional mass edit features for bulk changes
  • Annotated actions become available as table actions, properly integrated with selection states

Built-in Delete Feature

This intelligence means your users get the functionality they need without additional development effort on your part.

Multiple Visualizations at Your Fingertips

The portal showcases how a single building block can transform into different visualizations based on your requirements:

  • Responsive Table - Optimized for mobile and varying screen sizes
  • Grid Table - High-performance display for large datasets
  • Analytical Table - Built-in aggregation and grouping capabilities
  • Tree Table - Hierarchical data representation

But the capabilities don't stop there. The table building block comes packed with enterprise-grade features that users expect from modern business applications:

  • File Operations - Upload and download functionality for seamless document management
  • Data Export - Export to Excel and PDF for offline analysis
  • Clipboard Integration - Copy and paste operations for efficient data entry
  • Personalization - Column reordering, resizing, and hiding based on user preferences
  • Variant Management - Save and share different table configurations across users
  • Filtering & Sorting - Built-in capabilities for data exploration and organization
  • Mass Operations - Bulk actions and mass editing for productivity

And this is just the beginning - the portal showcases dozens of additional features that activate automatically based on your metadata annotations, entity capabilities and configuration. Each feature is documented with examples showing exactly how to enable it in your application.

Extensibility When Standard Features Aren't Enough

The portal demonstrates how building blocks balance out-of-the-box functionality with extensibility. When standard features don't meet your specific needs for, you can:

  • Add custom controls to display calculated or derived data
  • Integrate custom actions for business-specific operations
  • Use the building block API in your controller code for advanced scenarios

Custom Column in Table

This extensibility ensures you're never locked into standard behavior while still benefiting from enterprise-grade foundation features.

Multi-Format Code Examples: A New Level of Support

One of the portal's newest and most valuable features is showing the same annotations in multiple formats. When you explore a building block like the table, you'll see the implementation in:

  • CAP CDS - For SAP Cloud Application Programming Model development
  • RAP CDS - For ABAP RESTful Application Programming (since 1.142)
  • XML annotations - For local annotations when service changes aren't possible

Line Item Implementation

The portal's multi-format code examples ensure every developer can find the implementation pattern that fits their development context. CAP CDS examples offer full interactivity - modify annotations and see immediate results in the preview. RAP CDS examples provide static but comprehensive guidance for ABAP developers working in modern SAP environments, showing exactly how to implement the same functionality using ABAP RESTful Application Programming patterns. It also helps you find a running sample in the RAP Feature Showcase. XML annotations serve as your fallback option when service-level changes aren't feasible. This comprehensive approach means whether you're building with CAP, RAP, or working with existing services, you have the code examples you need to implement any building block feature.

See It in Action: Table Building Block Example

Let's explore the table's responsive behavior. When you open the Table Overview on a desktop, you'll see columns for ID, begin date, end date, agency, and status. But here's where the intelligence kicks in:

  1. Click "Show Code" next to the UI.LineItems annotation.
  2. The code editor opens, the preview adjusts to a smaller viewport, and you'll notice fewer columns are displayed.
    Note that the status column remains visible even though it's the 5th column in the annotation. This happens because of its @ui.Importance: #High setting.
  3. Now try changing @ui.Importance from #High to #Low and watch the status column disappear from the table in real-time.

Changing UI.Importance

This demonstrates how building blocks intelligently prioritize content based on your annotations and available screen space.

Interactive Learning Through Live Code

The portal's live code editing capability transforms learning from passive reading to active experimentation. You can:

  • Modify annotations and see immediate visual results
  • Test different configuration combinations
  • Understand the relationship between metadata and UI behavior
  • Experiment safely without affecting your actual development environment

This hands-on approach helps you understand not just what's possible, but how different annotation patterns affect the user experience and can serve as input for your app development.

What's Next

In our next post, "Use SAP Fiori development portal to understand extension options for standard floorplans (4 of 6)," we'll shift focus from individual building blocks to complete pages. We'll explore how the portal guides you through extending standard floorplans like List Report and Object Page, showing you exactly where and how to add custom functionality while maintaining the enterprise-grade foundation these pages provide.

To get the full overview about the SAP Fiori development portal, check out the following blog posts of the mini-series:

  • Introducing the SAP Fiori Development Portal: Your Gateway to Rapid SAP Fiori App Creation (1 of 6)
  • Get familiar with SAP Fiori development portal and the power of the building blocks (2 of 6)
  • Explore the potential of SAP Fiori development portal using complex building blocks (3 of 6)
  • Use SAP Fiori development portal to understand extension options for standard floorplans (4 of 6)
  • Prepare building custom pages by using SAP Fiori development portal (5 of 6)
  • Bringing the SAP Fiori development portal and its use to the next level (6 of 6)

entry.title: Test Data Refresh: Enhancing test tenant quality
entry.content:
We have seen how data migration is supported during 3SL conversion in our Data Migration for Test Environment Validation in ... - SAP Community blog, we have also seen how Test Data Conversion (TDC) plays a vital role in accelerating the test tenant readiness with valid depersonalised test data and system configurations from Previous quality tenant in Test Data Conversion, the accelerator: scaling sma... - SAP Community blog.  

Building on that foundation, this blog focuses on the next topic, Test Data Refresh (TDR) in the 3SL post conversion journey. TDR is a strategic service offered by SAP to ensure the availability of high quality, production like test data in the test tenant for all the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition customers. Let’s understand the purpose, value, and prerequisites of TDR, and realise how it enhances ongoing quality assurance and supports efficient testing environment. 

 

 TDR: Ongoing quality assurance: 

The TDR service is a subscription-based service with the flexibility of multi-use service designed to provide S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition customers with accurate, production-like data in their test tenant. It ensures that the test tenant reflects the latest application data from the production tenant, enabling realistic and effective testing scenarios.   

 

TDR offers a powerful solution for transferring production like data from the production tenant to the test tenant with the option of depersonalisation feature. It supports the migration of:  

  • Master Data  
  • Transactional Data  

 

TDR Pre-requisites:  

To have a smooth and flawless data transfer during the TDR implementation, the following key prerequisites must be fulfilled at the system level:  

  1. Uniform Software Release Across all tenants:  All Tenants must operate on the same software release configuration to eliminate system discrepancies and ensures reliable data flow.  
  2. System Configuration Maintenance: A well-maintained System configuration is essential for system stability there by reduces integration friction.   
  3. Content Version Alignment: All tenants should be in the same content version release to overcome errors during data transfer and could lead to incomplete data mapping.   
  4. Extension Readiness: Ensure all relevant extensions are active and configured with the latest updates by making use of The Handle Your Extensions application.  
  5. Clean Production Transport Queue: Make sure that there are no open transports in the development queue to avoid data inconsistency or conflicts.  

Note:  The TDR team will help you to validate and maintain the necessary configurations across tenants, thereby simplifying the process and ensuring the system readiness for TDR onboarding.  

 

TDR Process Overview: 

Customers can request TDR service any time during the year based on the Test Data Refresh calendar (kindly refer to the reference link section for the TDR calendar link).  

During the TDR process, the target (Test) tenant application data will be cleared, followed by a full refresh of application data from source (Production) tenant. This ensures the latest high quality and accurate test data availability in the testing tenant to facilitate efficient testing of the developments before moving to production tenant.  

Note: During TDR process, data in target tenant such as system configurations, user data and authorization data will be retained as it is. 

 To ensure data privacy, TDR service offers depersonalization as an optional feature, which ensures sensitive information (Workforce data is out of scope) is anonymized during the data transfer process.  

Note: Depersonalization is a broad and critical topic. Kindly refer to SAP help page to explore depersonalization in detail.  

 

Conclusion:  

In this Blog, we’ve explored the pre-requisite, scope of TDR. We've also seen how TDR enhances the quality of test data and enriching the test environment and supports a smoother transition to the new test tenant in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. 

We hope this has provided you with a comprehensive and clear understanding of TDR, its benefits, and its role in enabling a smoother transition to the new Test tenant.  

 

Reference: 

  • For more details about the Handle Your Extensions app and its use, refer to the Blog - Handle Your Extensions - test data refresh.  
  • Test Data Conversion, the accelerator: scaling sma... - SAP Community
  • Data Migration for Test Environment Validation in ... - SAP Community 
  • Calendar link : https://www.sap.com/documents/2023/08/d0ed9630-837e-0010-bca6-c68f7e60039b.html

rfcexec -a IM_HANA_ABAPADAPTER -g <Hostname> -x SAPGW<Instance no.> -s <SID> &

entry.title: SAP Integrated Business Planning (SAP IBP) 2511 - Available Now!
entry.content:
SAP Integrated Business Planning 2511 is now generally released and it's packed with powerful enhancements!

With three AI explainability features, we’re elevating visibility, usability, and efficiency for planners: AI-assisted forecast results analysis and AI-assisted inventory optimization analysis have been enhanced and are now available to all customers. The lineup is completed by the new AI-assisted supply optimization results analysis.

Don’t miss these and many more exciting features in SAP IBP 2511:

 

Smarter and Faster Decisions with AI-Assisted Supply Optimization Results Analysis


SAP Business AI in SAP IBP empowers planners to inquire about their supply planning runs including time series optimization. It boosts supply planner productivity by allowing easy comparison of different planning scenarios. Planners can quickly understand the results of supply optimizer planning, which leads to a reduction in lost sales and inventory costs.
The feature utilizes GenAI to analyze planning run logs, address encountered issues, providing suggestions for resolution, and comparing different planning runs to derive meaningful insights.


Key capabilities include a contextual conversational natural language interface enabled via Joule. Joule provides explanations for missed demand fulfillment, inventory targets, and manual adjustments, and recommends mitigation or gap closure options to achieve desired business outcomes.

 

 
Reach New Levels of Accuracy with AI-Assisted Forecast Results Analysis


With the AI-assisted forecast results analysis, planners can look under the hood of the forecast engine to get a comprehensive summary and detailed analysis of their latest forecast runs.
The tool offers actionable recommendations and provides comprehensive insights into the specific forecasting methods.

 

 
Enhance Planning Insights with AI-Assisted Inventory Optimization Analysis

 

Inventory planners can now request an analysis of the outcomes of their inventory optimization runs.
This feature helps make more informed decisions and refine inventory strategies effectively, allowing planners to swiftly adjust the inventory optimizer and/or supply chain model and communicate better with downstream users of inventory optimization targets.
The result: Higher adoption of inventory recommendations and improved analyst productivity.

 

 

Inventory/Characteristics-Based Planning (CBP)

Optimized Inventory Management with CBP-Based Safety Stock Levels


Applying safety stock levels to location products based on their characteristics-based planning (CBP) attributes allows for more precise inventory management. By leveraging key characteristic attributes, planners can now control inventory levels and achieve target service levels more effectively. This approach helps balance working capital investment and reduce obsolescence costs, ensuring optimal stock levels without overcommitting resources.


Key capabilities include the capacity to create safety stock targets for key characteristic combinations, allowing for tailored inventory strategies. It also enables the creation of supply elements via priority algorithms to achieve target inventory levels, ensuring that the right products are available in the right quantities at the right times.

 

 

Foundation

Smarter Master Data Management - Precision, Visibility, Collaboration


The new version of the Manage Master Data app delivers enhanced functionality with focus on planning area scope and master data relationships. Teams can collaborate more effectively by sharing standardized views through public variants, all while benefiting from robust, fine-grained access control through planning area-specific authorizations that ensure security across all operations.


In the new app, users can instantly target specific planning areas and versions for more efficient workflows, while exploring comprehensive parent-child connections and drilling down into dependencies for thorough impact assessment. The app enables personalized experiences through customizable columns, groupings, and sorting based on parent master data attributes.

 

Planning UIs

Easy Scenario Comparison with Scorecards in Planner Workspaces


Scorecards let you easily compare various what-if scenarios across multiple KPIs, helping planners make well-informed decisions, such as choosing the best-performing scenario. The initial scope of this feature was introduced in SAP IBP 2508 and has been further enhanced in this release.


A scorecard can include up to seven KPIs, each based on a key figure. For each KPI, you can set filters and specify an ideal direction: "Bigger is better," "Smaller is better", or "Within a range." If a key figure is added multiple times, you can use the new capability to rename KPIs. This enables separate views, for example “Capacity Supply for Assembly” and “Capacity Supply for Sub-Assembly”.
Comparisons between scenarios can be made using absolute or percentage differences. Once you identify the optimal scenario, you have the option to promote it directly from the scorecard.

 

 

Best Practices

Now Available: Best Practices Content for the Integrated Business Planning (I_SAPIBP2) Planning Area


We now offer SAP Best Practices content for the Integrated Business Planning (I_SAPIBP2) planning area, designed to streamline and enhance planning processes and help adopt the new planning area.


The content includes 17 solution processes covering the areas of Demand, Inventory, Response and Supply, and Sales and Operations. Users will benefit from deliverables like set guides, test scripts, planning views, Planner Workspaces, analytics stories, and sample data, all tailored to facilitate business process modelling, configuration, and process test execution. The predefined content is structured to accelerate implementation projects and mitigate risks, providing methodologies and tools that ensure a smooth transition to the new planning area. Additionally, the content is reusable and extendable, offering full flexibility for customization to meet unique customer requirements, thereby enhancing the value proposition of adopting the I_SAPIBP2 planning area.

 

 

More Information

  • SAP IBP What’s New Webinars 2511
  • 2511 What’s New: Help Portal Documentation
  • What’s New in Best Practices
  • SAP IBP Community Page
  • SAP IBP Roadmap
  • SAP Customer Influence Portal for SAP IBP
  • Questions? Ask here

entry.title: Integration Between SAP CPI and SAP DataSphere (JDBC Connection)
entry.content:
Integration Between SAP CPI and SAP DataSphere (JDBC Connection)

JDBC – JAVA DATABASE CONNECTIVITY

Why Recommendation for JDBC Over OData API :
JDBC is recommended over OData when consuming large-scale records (e.g., 100,000+) because JDBC streams data directly from the database with better performance and less overhead, while OData is optimized for lightweight, paginated, service-based access.

Problem statement: 3337495 - OData API returns less records than expected due paging
Pagination limits in OData and Ariba APIs can be handled in SAP CPI using a looping process call. I’ll cover this with a clear explanation in an upcoming post.

Goal: Connect CPI to a database used by DataSphere (JDBC) and run a simple read data from the (Analytical Model / Table /View).

For the Write / Delete / Update method, the attached SAP Help Portal Link has syntax in the reference section.

Prerequisites:

  1. SAP DataSphere – Subscribed account (⚠ Trial has limited features, JDBC not supported)
  2. SAP Integration Suite – Subscribed or Trial (JDBC actions supported)

 

SAP DataSphere Step by Step Guide :

Step

Action / Notes

1. Create a Space

DataSphere → Space Management → New Space → Name it → Create.

2. Create Table / Analytical Model

Data Builder → In your Space → New → Table or Analytical Model → define fields & data types → Save & Publish.
*Verify Table/Model Deployed Successfully. *

3. Prepare / Load Data

Load data manually for testing cases. Otherwise load CSV/import to table via Data Builder/Data Integration.

4. Note Schema & Object Names

Record schema name, table name, and view names for JDBC SQL use.
* Created space name is the SCHEMA name and Collect Table / Model name *

5. Decide Where to Create DB User

If HANA Cloud → use HANA Cockpit/DB Explorer. If on-prem DB → use DB admin tools or contact DB Admin.
* We are using the HANA cloud system for practical session*

6. Create JDBC DB User

DB admin tool → Security/Users → New User → set username & strong password → Save.
*Check Active status of User*

7. Grant Privileges for the DB user

Assign only required privileges (e.g., SELECT for read; add INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE for CRUD). Best practice: create role JDBC_ROLE and assign.

8. Prepare JDBC Connection Details

Gather JDBC URL (e.g.  sample URL from datasphere: z*********-abc.hana.prod-eu10.hanacloud.ondemand.com
Format for CPI JDBC Material:
jdbc:sap://<host>:<port>/?encrypt=true&validateCertificate=true


SAP Integration Suite Step by Step Guide :

Create a Package & Artifact

  • In CPI → Design → Create a new package → Add an integration flow artifact.
  • ✅ Make sure your CPI user has the required roles to create and access design-time artifacts.

Go to Monitoring → JDBC Material

  • In CPI → Monitor → Integrations and APIs → Manage Security → JDBC Material

     

  • → Add JDBC Data Source. → Select HANA cloud

     



  • Provide JDBC URL in the correct format (e.g., jdbc:sap://<hana-host>:443/?encrypt=true&validateCertificate=true).

     

  • Enter DB username and password (use the dedicated JDBC user created earlier in DataSphere).

     

  • Save and deploy the JDBC material.

Apply JDBC Material in iFlow

  • In your integration flow, configure the JDBC receiver adapter → select the JDBC data source created.
  • Use SQL queries (SELECT) in the Processing tab or provide XML query body. Here, I’m using SQL SELECT * to fetch all records from the table.

 


Step 1: Timer Start
 In this iFlow, the Start Timer is configured with a Simple Schedule → None → On Deployment, which means the integration flow automatically triggers immediately after deployment.

 


Step 2: Content Modifier
Use this SQL query to fetch all records with the body operation.
 SELECT * FROM "<Schema>"."<Model/TableName>"

 



Step 3: Request Reply & JDBC Receiver Adapter
 → Use the deployed JDBC Data Source alias in the JDBC Material in the previous step and set Max records count based on your requirement.
→ JDBC Maximum Records per call:  2,147,483,647

 


Sample data Response from JDBC Connection:

References :
same blog by me for clear picture quality: Integration of SAP CPI and SAP DataSphere using JD... - SAP Community
CPI JDBC – XML Query in Body for CRUD Operations (Syntax Guide)
 link:
https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-integration/sap-cloud-integration/payload-and-operation

entry.title: Re: BADI which will be triggered during batch creation
entry.content:
@RaghavanKathamuthu As per SPRO documentation there two sets of enhancements: one called during batch creation e.g. MSC1N, another one called during goods movement. In each set you have two enhancements: one to update batch master data, another one to update batch characteristics.

You don't need to call those enhancements - SAP standard code calls them automatically if the enhancements are implemented. All you need to do is to pick up the right enhancements according to your scenario and implement them.

entry.title: COC Operation: Revaluation of COGS vs. Scrapping Finished product
entry.content: In S4HC Public I have configured in the automatic account determination, for operation VAX/VAY and valuation category "finished product" the account 71201000 (COGS). Since we have actual costing, the COGS will be revaluated with operation COC, in which I have filled the same account. Besides, we have activated the COGS split Based on Cost Components for that account. My doubt is if I post a good issue against cost center because of scrapping (operation GBB-VNG) with account 71200000 (VARIATION INV. FINISHED PRODUCTS), when executing CKMLCP, if there are price differences accumulated, the account 71201000 (COGS) will be posted against the cost center because of COC operation, and a second posting with the COGS splitting will be made. This would be wrong. What should i do if I want to distinguish revaulation of sales to be posted with 71201000 and revaluation of consumption against cost center with 71200000 (and therefore no splitting), when I can only fill one account in the automatic account determination for the combination of operation COC and valuation category "finished product"?

entry.title: Suggestion: Link the linked accounts
entry.content:
(I tried to start this as a suggestion, but it seems I have no enough privileges, so I must bother you with a normal post)

So I had this account for years, since I fell in the SAP world circa 2004. It's linked to my personal e-mail account, and I want to keep it that way to preserve my sad and useless history of contributions here. Because it's a personal one, it's a P account. No problem with that.

But as I need to keep working with SAP, my company registered me another account linked to my company e-mail address. Because it's a professional one, and I assume my company pays for it somehow, it's an S account. Nice.

What's my problem? I join everyday here with my P account, I dig for info, and sometimes I find someone telling "check the XXXX note". So I go to me.sap.com to check that note and... I have no authorization there. I check my account info and I see both accounts linked, but the system is uncapable of decide that if I am in the support section, I must be treated as an S account, and treat me as a P account while in the community one.

So I must log out, log in again and keep doing that every day.

Please, try to change that behaviour to allow us with linked S&P accounts to be treated according to the section.

(it's curious how the post changed when I noticed "treat" comes without "h")

entry.title: Re: BAPI_ROUTING_CREATE
entry.content:
Hello there

Your code is rather difficult to read. Please do consider using the code sample formatting option.

There seem to be several issues here:

  •  The error itself means that you are missing links between the different internal tables, i.e. how these records belong together. The BAPI won't know, whether you want to create one routing for one material with several operations or several routings for several materials with one operation or what - unless you tell the BAPI exactly what to do. Which you can achieve by specifying GROUP_COUNTER in the relevant tables to establish the link between these records.
  • Based on your input data, it seems you want to create one routing for one material with 11 operations. Yet, you loop at your input data and create not only multiple it_op records, but also multiple it_task and it_mat_task_allo records
  • Lastly, perhaps it is just formatting, but based on your GUI_UPLOAD call, the input file should be TAB separated. This doesn't seem to be the case.

entry.title: Could an SAP SD career be a good choice for you?
entry.content:
Is becoming an SAP Sales and Distribution (SD) Consultant a good career choice? Short answer: Yes.

Longer answer:

The SD consultant manages the process from taking a customer order to getting paid (called Order-to-Cash). This job is highly demanded right now.

1.  Why is this job a good investment?

High Demand and Good Salary:

Migration Pressure: Only about 37% of SAP customers have moved to the new S/4HANA system. This means 63% still need to move. This huge amount of work means consultants are needed for many years to come, which keeps salaries high.  

2.  Is SAP SD the right module for you?

You should choose SD if you have experience or interest in: Sales, Logistics, Shipping, or Order Management. Success is about understanding the business, not just clicking buttons.  

Key skills to master:

You need the basics, plus these high-value skills in S/4HANA:

  • Pricing Procedures: You must know how to set up complex pricing rules. 
  • Integration: Know how SD connects with Finance (FI) and Inventory (MM).  
  • Advanced ATP (aATP): This is the new tool for checking stock availability. Master aATP to help clients manage product shortages and prioritize orders for important customers.  
  • FSCM Credit: SAP moved Credit Management to the Finance module. You must understand this new setup to integrate sales and finance properly.  

Advices for beginners:

Experience first: Most companies want consultants with 3–4 years of experience.  

Best starting path: If you don’t find your way to consultancy positions; Try to get a job as an SAP end-user in a related area (like Order Management) for 1–2 years. This gives you the real-world business knowledge that consultants need.  

Practice then Practice: You can get a free S/4HANA trial system, set up a pretend company, and practice the processes yourself. This is great for interviews.  

3.  The Future: AI and the SD Consultant

Will AI (like SAP Joule) take your job? No.

AI will automate many routine tasks, but it will not replace the consultant. AI will change your job to focus on higher value work:  

  • Less basic setup: AI helps with basic setup and testing tasks.  
  • More strategy: Your new role is to check the AI's work and focus on complex problems. You will also help clients use AI features (like predictive analytics) to make better decisions, such as optimizing their inventory levels.  
  • Clean Code: You must become an expert at reducing complex custom code inside the main system (this is called Clean Core) to make the system easier to update.  

The SAP SD career is a strong investment if you focus on the new S/4HANA specialties and you love it.

entry.title: How to handle rejected stock lots on EWM with HU
entry.content:
We need to bring back the restricted batch status to unrestricted batch status and the blocked stock to unrestricted stock type which has been already rejected by quality. Decentralized EWM, Pharma industry.

Business case

It is possible that after the batch is rejected, not all the quantity will share the same decision. Assuming we have 100 units rejected, maybe only 20 would be discarded, and 80 to be reprocessed or shipped to customer or whatever the decision may be. the decision can be done in parts. meaning today decision for 20 to be discarded. 1 month later, the decision for the reamining 80 to be reprocessed.

Also it is possible that some quantity is rejected, but the overall inspection lot is released. and the rejected HUs can have a different decision. Example. rejected 5 units out of 100 units. the 5 units that are rejected, 2 will be discarded, 3 will be use for other purpose. 

Pain point:

1. How to change the batch status for each lot quantity from same batch.
2. Changing the batch status will change the status for whole lot. How can we do it particularly for respective HU & Batch. Here the rework.
3. How to handle the Usage decision for rejected HU and batch as the decision will take a long while for different parts.
4. In EWM how the stock will be traced. We have 4 screnario where we can scrap, ship, rework, Reuse the rejected part.
5. How can we trace the rejected stock movements in EWM and S4. How to identify that is rejected stock and its be moved due to quality issue. both in shopfloor and SAP
6. If we are doing rework how to release the rejected batch and at the same time not to consider this for MRP and other process order.
7. If we are doing shipment how to consider the MPR and no consumption against other sale/delivery.
8. How the quality certificates will be traced for normal and rejected same batch lots.

Do combining quality notification, custom action box and quality task solve this problem.

entry.title: Actual Costing in S/4HANA – Single-Level Only Possible?
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I’m currently working with a customer who is interested in using Actual Costing to improve their material valuation process.
The goal would be to post production variances directly to the material itself – similar to how purchase price differences are already included for raw materials – but without rolling them up through multiple BOM levels.

For example, the customer produces prefabricated components (“prefabs”) from raw materials.
Each prefab should reflect its own actual production and procurement variances, while higher-level assemblies that use these prefabs should be valuated at the current PUP (periodic unit price).

From what I remember, under ECC the process steps for Single-Level and Multilevel Valuation were executed separately during the Actual Costing run.
I’m not completely sure whether this setup actually allowed a single-level-only approach, but it looked like the logic could be separated.
In S/4HANA, these steps seem to have been merged into one single phase called Settlement.

My question is therefore:
Is there still a way in S/4HANA to perform only single-level valuation, so that variances are applied directly to the material without rolling them up to higher-level products?
Or is this no longer possible with the new Actual Costing design?

We use S/4HANA on premise 2023. 

Thanks in advance for any insights or experience!

Best regards,
Olga

entry.title: Auto Clearing of Invoices and Credit Memos in SAP Public Cloud
entry.content:
The client has requested auto clearing functionality in SAP Public Cloud to automatically clear invoices reference against credit memos when both have the same values.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Auto Clearing of Invoices and Credit Memos in SAP Pub...
entry.content:
SAP Public Cloud supports the automatic clearing of open items from customer, supplier and G/L accounts (in particular, GR/IR clearing accounts). It selects all accounts that are specified in the value sets and that have debit and credit postings.

 

In order to set up the clearing program to run automatically as scheduled, you will need to prepare 2 tasks.

  • First, you need to identify criteria for automatic clearing validation. In Manage Your Solution, follow SSCUI 101971 - Prepare Automatic Clearing to define criteria according to your requirements. Please note that up to five selections are supported for this configuration.
  • Second, you will schedule the clearing program to run automatically with Automatic Clearing app. According to your request, you will tick on "Select Customers" checkbox, and enter the list of customer number here for reconciliation, together with other parameters.

 

The remaining open items are grouped according to fixed system criteria:

  • Company code
  • Account type
  • Account number
  • Reconciliation account number
  • Currency key
    • BSID-WAERS for customers
    • BSIK-WAERS for suppliers
    • BSIS-PSWSL for G/L accounts
  • Special G/L indicator

 

Clearing only execute when the balance in document currency is zero for the group of customer line items selected according to the above criteria. 

Additionally, certain items are excluded from automatic clearing, such as:

  • Noted items
  • Statistical postings and special G/L transactions of the type bill of exchange
  • Items with withholding tax postings
  • Down payments, unless down payment clearing for the same amount has been posted

entry.title: End-to-End Shell Copy Scenario in Software Provisioning Manager (SWPM) 1.0
entry.content:
• Introduction
  • Step 1: System Export
  • 1. Download the Latest SWPM:
  • 2. Start SWPM & Select Scenario
  • 3. Set Source System Parameters
  • 4. Trigger Export with SUM 2.0
  • 5. Transfer Export Directory
  • Step 2: System Provisioning (Import on Target Host)
  • 1. Prepare Target Database
  • 2. Install ASCS Instance
  • 3. Provide SAPEXE Kernel and SAP Host Agent Binaries
  • 4. Import Database Shell Instance
  • 5. Install the Stub Primary Application Server (PAS)
  • Step 3: Post-Copy Activities
  • Tips & Recommendations
  • Useful Links

 

Introduction

Shell Copy is a new scenario introduced in SWPM 1.0 to support digital transformation with SAP Business Transformation Center.  For more information, see [Everything about using SAP Business Transformation center for SDT S/4 HANA Conversion 2023 from ECC].  

The shell copy scenario helps you prepare an SAP ERP shell system containing all Dictionary and Repository objects and all Customizing - while excluding application data. For more insights, please see the introductory blog: [Reducing the DataBase Size of SAP ERP Systems Using Shell Copy Scenario]. 

Below, you'll find an example workflow that demonstrates a typical Shell Copy procedure using SWPM 1.0 for SAP ERP 6.0 EHP8 on Linux. The process consists of three main phases: system export, system provisioning, and post-copy steps.  

IMPORTANT: Always consult the latest SAP product documentation and Shell Copy Guide specific to your operating system and database platform. Review and apply all relevant SAP Notes before starting the Shell Copy scenario on your landscape. 

 

Step 1: System Export

1. Download the Latest SWPM:  
  • Obtain the latest SWPM 1.0 for NW higher than 7.0x SAR file supporting Shell Copy from SAP Software Center. 
  • Review prerequisites: "Running Software Provisioning Manager". 
2. Start SWPM & Select Scenario 
  • In the Product Catalog, select: SAP Business Suite 7i 2016 → EHP8 for SAP ERP 6.0 ABAP → <DB Type> → Shell Copy → Source System → Database Instance Shell Export 

 

3. Set Source System Parameters 
  • Confirm or enter the path to the SAP ECC profile folder 

  • Enter <sid> adm password when prompted. 

 

  • Provide the DDIC user’s password in client 000 (needed for online preparation). 

4. Trigger Export with SUM 2.0 
  • In the Shell Copy scenario, Software Update Manager (SUM) 2.0 replaces Migration Monitor for database migration. 

  • Specify the export directory path where SWPM will extract and run SUM. 
  • Download and provide the latest SUM 2.0 archive from the SAP Software Center. 

  • Confirm the “Parameter Summary” dialog to trigger exports. 
5. Transfer Export Directory 
  • When export is completed, copy the entire export directory to the target host (including SUM and data). 

Step 2: System Provisioning (Import on Target Host) 

1. Prepare Target Database 
  • Set up the target database per the installation guide for SAP ERP 6.0. Under “Product Release”, make sure that you select “SAP NetWeaver 7XX-based”. 
  • Tip: Review and apply required SAP Notes required for Shell Copy 
    that resolve known issues. 
2. Install ASCS Instance 
  • Start SWPM 1.0 on the target and choose: SAP Business Suite 7i 2016 → EHP8 for SAP ERP 6.0 ABAP → <DB Type> → Shell Copy → Target System → ASCS Instance 
  • The SAP system ID (SAPSID) must remain the same between source and target (e.g., if source is SC1, target must also be SC1). 
  • In that example we provide a Master Password for all system users such, e.g. <sid>adm, SAPService<SAPSID>. If you did not create the operating system users manually before the installation, the Software Provisioning Manager creates them with the common Master Password. If users are not pre-created, SWPM will create them. 
  • For master password requirements, refer to he SAP System Parameters section of the installation guide. 
3. Provide SAPEXE Kernel and SAP Host Agent Binaries 
  • SWPM will prompt for SAPEXE Kernel archive and the SAP Host Agent binary files - have them ready. 
4. Import Database Shell Instance 
  • On the target DB host, launch SWPM and select: SAP Business Suite 7i 2016 → EHP8 for SAP ERP 6.0 ABAP → <DB Type> → Shell Copy → Target System → Database Shell Instance 
  • For standard installation (all instances on one host), /sapmnt/ is local and SWPM will detect profile directory. 
  • Use the previously set master password and <sid>adm password 
  • Enter the same DBSID as used in the source system.
  • Provide the required SAP Kernel resources
  • Specify the SUM export directory path you copied earlier. 
  • Note: If changing CPU architecture (e.g., Windows to Linux), provide the appropriate SUM.SAR for the new OS on the target system

  • Address any DB-specific dialogs without making unsupported changes to the DB layer. 
5. Install the Stub Primary Application Server (PAS) 
  • Launch SWPM and choose: SAP Business Suite 7i 2016 → EHP8 for SAP ERP 6.0 ABAP → <DB Type> → Shell Copy → Target System → Stub Primary Application Server Instance 
  • Specify the instance profile folder. 
  • Use the previously set master password. 
  • Provide archives for SAPEXE, IGSEXE, and IGSHelper as requested. 
  • Address any DB-specific dialogs. 
  • Once the PAS instance installation has been completed, the Shell ABAP system should be up and running. 

Step 3: Post-Copy Activities 

The last step is to prepare the Shell ERP system as described in the Follow-Up Activities section of the Shell Copy Guide for your operating system and platform. 

Tips & Recommendations 
  • Prepare required SAP Notes in advance to avoid interruptions. 
  • Use the latest supported versions of SWPM and SUM. 
  • Avoid DB layer changes between source and target unless explicitly supported by SAP. 
  • Master passwords should comply with all OS-level security policies. 
Useful Links 
  • SAP Software Center 
  • Shell Copy Guide 
  • Post-Copy Activities 
  • SAP Notes required for Shell Copy 
  • “Reducing DB Size of SAP ERP systems via Shell Copy Scenario” 

By following these steps, you can efficiently perform a shell copy of your SAP ERP landscape using SWPM 1.0 and SUM 2.0.

entry.title: Info/Links for TechEd Community Talk CT1293 - SAP Build Control Tower
entry.content:
This post is to provide additional reference information and links related to my community talk CT1293 - Get control of the control tower feature in SAP Build solutions. See you there.

Control Tower Layout

Here's is the current picture of the Control Tower.

I think the layout is simple and clean, though it has evolved with additional tiles over the last 2 years and I don't think it's so clear how everything is inter-related. Here is my annotated version with a few notes. 

My notes:

  • Environments, introduced relatively recently with the public environment deprecated, seems to me the central most-important tile on the page
  • Destinations and API keys are strongly connected to environments
  • The first 3 tiles are related to transport: The first defines whether the tenant is dev/qa/prod for the sake of transport, and the governance rules (next 2 tiles) in part add an extra layer of approval for transport operations. The rules also affect simply creating a project.

More information on the Control Tower: https://help.sap.com/docs/build-service/build-service-guide/managing-control-tower?locale=en-US

Permissions

There are many layers of permissions within SAP Build. Here they are from highest to lowest level.

IAS

Identity Authentication Service (IAS), or perhaps now just Cloud Identity Service, is the very first level and at the most basic level lets you create new users.

I just want to point out one helpful feature are groups. I can set up a group and then assign that group role connections. When I have a new user I just add them to the group and they inherent all the role collections. 

Here are groups in IAS.

Here I assign a group to a role collection. Note that SAP BTP does not have a dropdown of groups so you have to simply type in the name of the group.

YOu can do the same with attributes, for example, assign a role collection based on job function or home country.

More information: https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/landing-page?locale=en-US

Tenants

Once you have a user in IAS, you can assign that user to a tenant and NOT assign them to other tenants. You can look in the Users page to see which users have access to the current tenant.

More information: https://help.sap.com/docs/btp/sap-business-technology-platform/business-users?locale=en-US

Roles

Once a user has access to the tenant in some way, you determine what they can do on that tenant by assigning them roles, not directly, but through role collections, which are sets of roles that loosely map to a persona (e.g., admin, developer, business user, super user).

Here's more information on the specific roles/role collections related to the low-code tools of SAP Build:

  • SAP Build Apps: https://help.sap.com/docs/build-apps/service-guide/configuring-user-roles?locale=en-US&q=role
  • SAP Build Process Automation: https://help.sap.com/docs/build-process-automation/sap-build-process-automation/authorizations?locale=en-US&q=role
  • SAP Build Work Zone: https://help.sap.com/docs/build-work-zone-standard-edition/sap-build-work-zone-standard-edition/about-roles-and-role-assignments?locale=en-US&q=role

Design-Time Authorizations

These authorizations are done on the project level, some know as collaboration authorizations, so you can work with others on specific projects.

For information on the meaning of each role, see https://help.sap.com/docs/build-service/build-service-guide/managing-project-members?locale=en-US.

Runtime Automarizations

Runtime authorizations are the authorizations you have within environments. Environments are separate areas for deploying projects, and each environment can be set up to allow different users to do different activities (e.g., view, deploy, add users).

For information on the meaning of each role, see https://help.sap.com/docs/build-service/build-service-guide/share-environment.

Governance Rules

Governance rules let you set up a process to be executed so managers can approve or reject whether another user can create a project or transport a project.

If you enable rules for either creation or transport, you are automatically given into the lobby an out-of-the-box process and action. You must deploy the process before the rules can take effect (the action is automatically published). Before deploying, you can modify the process -- you really must since it the process automatically gives the requestor the right to approve his own project.

For more information, see https://help.sap.com/docs/build-service/build-service-guide/governance?locale=en-US&q=governance+rules.

Transport

Transport allows you to create formal processes for moving projects from one tenant to another tenant, generally from DEV > QA > PROD. The transport does not deploy projects but simply moves the design-time projects from one SAP Build installation to another. You can only transport a released version.

You will have to install Cloud Transport Manager Service, and add the Content Agent Service on every tenant to which you want to transport content. 

Once you have everything setup and execute a transport from the SAP Build lobby, the package goes to CTMS, where someone with the import role will need to approve the transport. 

For more information on setting up transport, see https://community.sap.com/t5/application-development-and-automation-blog-posts/transporting-content-in-sap-build-apps-sap-cloud-transport-management/ba-p/13737478.

For more information on how to transport and prerequisites, see https://help.sap.com/docs/build/sap-build-core/transport-project?locale=en-US&q=transport.
